Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC Center for UAS Site Addition (Virginia Tech)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Center for Unmanned Aircraft Systems (C-UAS), an Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) established by Brigham Young University and the University of Colorado in 2012, provides innovative solutions to key technical challenges facing the UAS industry and trains a diverse, highly qualified cadre of leaders for this emerging field. In seeking to join the C-UAS, as a third university site, Virginia Tech brings expertise in a variety of critical and complementary research areas. Virginia Tech also leads one of six FAA-designated unmanned aircraft system test sites, which presents an opportunity for C-UAS partners to support the FAA's regulatory policy development efforts while establishing a foothold in emerging commercial markets. This planning grant supports Virginia Tech's effort to develop a viable, self-sustaining Site Addition to the C-UAS.

The specific research agenda to be addressed within this C-UAS Site Addition will ultimately be determined by the Center's Industry Advisory Board (IAB), including new representatives who commit to join the Center along with Virginia Tech. Likely focus areas for the expanded C-UAS research program include advanced flight control (e.g., methods to construct robust, secure, and mathematically certified control algorithms), agriculture (e.g., methods to monitor plant pathogen transport), machine vision and machine learning (e.g., software for real-time, on-board intelligent image processing), multiphysics design optimization (e.g., aircraft design optimization tools that incorporate unsteady fluid/structure interaction), safety and airworthiness (e.g., reliability prediction methods that incorporate imprecise uncertainties intrinsic to small UAS), and wireless communications (e.g., the use of software defined radio and intelligent communication protocols that adapt the information flow to the environmental conditions). Proposals for specific research tasks will be developed in coordination with prospective industry and government partners to ensure that those partners are fully engaged in the process and committed to the research program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of ths project was to support Virginia Tech's entry as a third university site in the Center for UAS (C-UAS), an NSF I/UCRC initiated by BYU and CU-Boulder. Objectives supporting the project goal included (1) hosting a planning meeting in Arlington, VA on February 10, 2015, (2) proposing candidate projects to the C-UAS Industry Advisory Board (IAB) meeting in Boulder, CO on August 5-6, 2015 and (3) submitting a formal Site Addition proposal to the NSF.

(1) A planning meeting was held at Virginia Tech's Arlington, VA facility on February 10, 2015 in conjunction with the C-UAS IAB meeting there on February 11-12. More than 40 prospective industry and government members were invited to participate and more than a dozen of these sent delegates. In addition, several representatives from the existing IAB attended the planning meeting. The agenda included presentations from the C-UAS Director (Prof. Tim McLain), NSF I/UCRC program affiliates (Drs. Rita Rodriguez and Alex Schwarzkopf), and the C-UAS Evaluator (Dr. Eric Sundstrom). There were 10 candidate research proposals from VT faculty members, evaluated by the prospective members using the L.I.F.E. process, as well as a half-dozen posters prepared by VT students.

(2) Based on the L.I.F.E. feedback during the February Planning Meeting, seven
project proposals were down-selected for presentation by VT faculty to the August 2015 IAB meeting in Boulder, CO. These project proposals were again evaluated according to the L.I.F.E. process by the existing IAB and by prospective IAB members who committed to joining the C-UAS with Virginia Tech should a VT Site be established.

(3) Five prospective members submitted letters committing to join a proposed VT Site, should it be approved by the NSF, and these letters were included in a formal proposal that was submitted to NSF in March 2015. The letters of commitment were provided by the Army Research Laboratory, L-3 Unmanned Systems, NASA Langley Research Center, NAVAIR, and Stantec Corporation.

The proposal to establish a Virginia Tech Site within the Center for UAS was
approved for funding by the NSF and the VT Site was established on September 15, 2015. Efforts to obtain member fees began immediately afterward. Four initial projects, selected based on L.I.F.E. evaluations at the August 2015 IAB meeting, were initiated under C-UAS sponsorship in January 2016.
